activities.message: any updates sir ? it's has been 15 minute without any updates ! please fix it .. just add <? and everything will be ok

activities.message:
*Rolls d20 for Diplomacy to attempt to reply with tact. Rolls a 1.*

This is very silly and a total waste of both of our time. But let's cast aside common sense and good taste for a moment. At the risk of having publicly humored a Markov bot, let's indulge the allegation set forth in this report.

> Anyway, I've found that your code here https://github.com/paragonie/airship/blob/master/tools/audit_helper.php , is starting with <?php and it should be with ?> ... any hacker like me can run HTML code on this page so you should close the source by <? ... 

Okay, I can't parse this in one sitting. Let's digest it bit by bit and see if it makes sense:

1. A nonessential command line utility that simply selects a random file and tells you audit it for possible security risks "is starting with <?php and it should be with ?>".
  * I take that back, breaking that into pieces doesn't offer any insight or clarity here.
  * What would starting a PHP script with `?>` even accomplish?
2. "any hacker like me can run HTML code on this page so you should close the source by <?"
  * This isn't a web page, it's a command line utility.
  * What does "run HTML code on this page" even mean?
  * What do you mean by "close the source by `<?`"?

> any updates sir ? it's has been 15 minute without any updates ! please fix it .. just add <? and everything will be ok 

So, one of three things happened here.

1. Your account was hacked by someone looking to trash your reputation.
2. You have no idea what you're doing.
3. You're a particularly clever Markov bot seeded by other H1 vulnerability report comments.

I'm closing this as Invalid and publishing via full disclosure.

activities.message: @paragonie-scott I'm very sorry for reporting this issue at Hackerone I didn't know about that. it seems to be I should report it via Github right ?

activities.message:
> he is don't know anything about coding .. as we learned in PHP .. if we start an PHP file by <?php we should close it by ?>.. anyway .. ok .. here is example >>
> 
> <?php
> 
> echo "Hello world";
> 
> ?>

So, wait, your entire point here is that you believe PHP scripts MUST end in a `?>` tag? 

From [the PHP manual](http://php.net/basic-syntax.instruction-separation):

>  The closing tag of a PHP block at the end of a file is optional, and in some cases omitting it is helpful when using include or require, so unwanted whitespace will not occur at the end of files, and you will still be able to add headers to the response later. It is also handy if you use output buffering, and would not like to see added unwanted whitespace at the end of the parts generated by the included files. 

And, in fact, the PSR-2 standard [requires `?>` to be omitted](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-2/#2-2-files).

But even if both points weren't true, there's no vulnerability here.
activities.markdown_message:
he is don't know anything about coding .. as we learned in PHP .. if we start an PHP file by <?php we should close it by ?>.. anyway .. ok .. here is example >>

<?php

echo "Hello world";

?>

So, wait, your entire point here is that you believe PHP scripts MUST end in a ?> tag?

From the PHP manual:

The closing tag of a PHP block at the end of a file is optional, and in some cases omitting it is helpful when using include or require, so unwanted whitespace will not occur at the end of files, and you will still be able to add headers to the response later. It is also handy if you use output buffering, and would not like to see added unwanted whitespace at the end of the parts generated by the included files.

And, in fact, the PSR-2 standard requires ?> to be omitted.

But even if both points weren't true, there's no vulnerability here.
